history.content:
<md>putting aside the arrogance in your post, i don’t think you realize how much work it is to offer alternate exams – shrinking enrollments are a direct result of the fact that it’s becoming harder to hire enough staff to run eecs courses the way they should be run, and what you’re effectively suggesting is that in light of constraints on staff hours, the instructors are somehow to blame for not being logistically able to accommodate students _due to the same lack of staff hours_.

having conflicting final exam times is also not as likely as you suggest. i’m coming into my sixth semester here and have never had a conflicting exam time, and according to the registrar, won’t have one next semester either. not only that, but most courses make it very clear whether or not they’ll allow alternate final exam times early on in the semester, so in most cases you’d be well aware of what you’re signing up for.

i don’t know if you’ve been reading some of the posts around this piazza lately, but the department’s kind of in a tight spot, and as a result so are all the instructors and student staff, who work around the clock to make sure that their relevant courses run as smoothly as possible. calling instructors “irresponsible” in the face of increasingly limited staff resources is probably not a great way to be heard, even if the rest of your point was a valid concern.</md>

i don’t think you realize how much work it is to offer alternate exams – shrinking enrollments are a direct result of the fact that it’s becoming harder to hire enough staff to run eecs courses the way they should be run, and what you’re effectively suggesting is that in light of constraints on staff hours, the instructors are somehow to blame for not being logistically able to accommodate students due to the same lack of staff hours.

children.subject:
Speaking as an instructor:
I DO offer alternate exams, but I really understand those who don't.  There is a lot of overhead in extra exam times etc.

Especially for finals, conflicting exams only occur if you are taking classes who's lectures have a time conflict anyway, which instructors don't have to allow.

Great place to waste the budget on, and thus, further reduce number of upper-divs you will be able to take 👍

Also, your logical ability is very concerning. Given the fewer available upper-divs, it's actually easier to plan their final time slots s.t. these popular courses will not conflict - not the other way around - regardless of whether that might or might not happen due to instructors' already exploded workload.

@anon beaker why do you keep editing vanshaj's response lol? Also +1 scheduling alternate exams is a huge hassle (especially in an person setting where space is another constraint) and not the best use of staff hours when budgets are being cut across the board.

history.subject: Not offering alternative final exam is irresponsibility of instructors

history.content: Given we have very limited upper-div CS classes to take and shrunk enrollment amount, it's more like for us to have conflicting final exams. It's irresponsible to not offer alternative final exams for instructors. If EECS department could obligate instructors to offer alternative final exams, students could benefit a lot more.
history.subject: Not offering alternative final exam is irresponsibility of instructors

history.content: Given we have very limited upper-div CS classes to take and shrunk enrollment amount, it's more like for us to have conflicting final exams. It's irresponsible to not offer alternative final exams for instructors. If EECS department could obligate instructors to offer alternative final exams, students could benefit a lot more.
history.subject: Not offering alternative final exam is irresponsibility of instructors

history.content: Given we have very limited upper-div CS classes to take and shrunk enrollment amount, it's more like for us to have conflicting final exams. It's irresponsible to not offer alternative final exams for instructors. I propose that EECS department should obligate instructors to offer alternative final exams.
history.subject: Not offering alternative final exam is irresponsibility of instructors
